transcripts.text: Welcome back.  It's Crime Time here on Court TV Live.  Let's introduce tonight's law enforcement professionals who are with us.  Joining us, retired Los Angeles Police Department Sergeant Cheryl Dorsey.  Sergeant Dorsey started with the LAPD in 1980.  She worked in patrol and specialized units, including gangs.  And she's also the author of Black and Blue, The Creation of a Social Advocate.  Also with us, Assistant Chief Jailer, former Chief of the Major Crime Section, Lieutenant Colonel Adam Lee III.  Adam served as a police officer for 30 years.  He oversaw homicide cases, robberies, special victim units, and a gun assault team.  And he's the former Assistant Police Academy Director.  Lots of experience, lots of knowledge.  Let's get to our first story tonight.  We've got this video.  It comes to us from the Phoenix Police Department.  And this is a man pretending to have a gun.  Let's take a look.
Is he still out there?  Who's she?
He, Jordan.  Who's he?
His name is Jordan Crawford.

Why is he not supposed to be here, ma'am?  He doesn't live here.  He's my ex-boyfriend, and he's not supposed to be here.  I threw him out about two weeks ago, three weeks ago, and I told him not to come back.  Well, he called, and he didn't have a place to sleep, so I let him sleep.
I said, you have to leave in the morning, and he won't leave.
He will not leave, and this is what the problem was last time.
I will never let him in my house again, ever.
Don't do it.  But he's not, I mean, he can't be in your house, but he can't be in the complex unless he's been trespassed from here.
Do you know if he's been trespassed from here?
Not yet.  He will be.  He was down at the neighbor's house.  They called me.

I don't know which neighbor because I don't know any of my neighbors, but he's been out here since.  And he's your ex-boyfriend?  Uh-huh.  Have you thought about... Obtaining an order of protection.  Another one?  Yeah.  No, the other one expired in October, I believe.
So that would be a...
But he currently has a warrant.
I do know that.
Hey, Jordan!
Come... Hey, what's behind your back, dude?  You have a gun?  Don't do that.
Don't do that, bro.
He's saying he's got a gun.
Jordan, show us your hands right now, brother.  Show me your hands right now, brother.

I don't want him going into that street.  Jordan, we don't want to kill you, dude!  It's all just a part of my dream!  Stop right there!  Jordan, stop it right now, brother!  Stop!  Okay, he's gonna kill someone!  Stop!  You decide!  Stop!  You decide!  You decide!  Jordan!  Five!  Four!  Three!  Two!  Jordan!
During the investigation, a weapon was not recovered.
All right, it's a tragic end, and we saw how it ended when he pulled his hand from behind his back after concealing it the whole time.  Was there any other way to handle this?  Sergeant Dorsey.

Well, listen, this seems to be a case of suicide by cop.  My only criticism is that I don't think the officers communicated with one another prior to engaging the suspect.  I don't see why every officer seemingly... emptied their clip.  They should have had one designated shooter if they needed one, and everybody else should have stood by.

Lieutenant Colonel, I look at this, and he's got his hand.  He's telling them he has a gun.  He won't show his hand.  He does this countdown and then pulls his arm out.  Are there any alternative ways to approach the situation or... Or is it what it is?  And as the sergeant said, it seems a lot very consistent with suicide by cop.

It's easy for us to critique it after we see the video and we can tell how many different things we could have done.  But when you're in the moment, it's very difficult not to do what these officers did.  If somebody tells you they have a gun, you should believe them.  You know, there's no reason for those officers to not believe that he really had a weapon.  Obviously, this young man is suffering from some sort of a mental illness because no one in their right minds would challenge police officers the way he did.  And he did the countdown, you know, so it's obvious to me that he has some sort of mental deficiency.  I really feel bad for the officers because I'm sure when they discovered he was unarmed, their hearts probably dropped.  You know, it's a situation where they're going to be investigated and who knows what's going to be the outcome.  But we have to realize that officers have less than a split second, sometimes a quarter of a second, to make these life and death situations, these decisions.

Yeah, and as I was watching that video myself and he pulls the hand around, I could not tell one way or the other.  All I could see was that the arm was coming out and it was going straight out.  So tragic across the board.  Next story comes to us from WFTS in Tampa, Florida.  A deputy arrested for texts after the Capitol riots.
Need to make the streets of D.C.  run red with blood of the tyrants.

Text messages outline several violent threats allegedly sent by Polk County Deputy Peter Haneen.  Investigators say Haneen was fired up watching the violent riots play out at the U.S.  Capitol.  Texting should have drugged those tyrants out into the streets and executed them, sick of the corruption.
And there's a line.  And Peter Haneen crossed the line between ugly talk and threats.  That's what got him arrested.
Sheriff Grady Judd says Haneen's comments targeted the FBI.
Any cop or military who stands in the way is the enemy.

Tonight, Polk County investigators are searching the deputy's home, reviewing his social media accounts.  This comes as D.C.  is on high alert, the National Guard sidelining a dozen service members ahead of Inauguration Day.  Tonight, the sheriff praising another deputy who notified them about the messages, calling him a hero.
I tell my deputies that doing what's right is not always easy, but it's always right.  And he stood in the face of not only one of his colleagues, but one of his friends.
Hanin is charged with felony for written threats.  He has now been suspended while the termination process plays out.
All right, the termination is an obvious move here, right?  I mean, that's an obvious one.  How about arresting him?  Was that the right move?  Lieutenant Colonel Adam Lay III.

He absolutely should be arrested.  That made me sick to see the text that that young man wrote.  In our oath as law enforcement officers, it says that we will faithfully and impartially discharge our duties as peace officers to the best of our ability, so help me God.  And to the best of my ability is not a disclaimer.  It doesn't allow us to impart our political views, our biases, or whatever, in order to do our jobs.  And this officer absolutely, like the sheriff said, he crossed the line.  I'm sure if they looked at his background, he probably should not have been hired in the first place.  It makes me sick to watch that, Benny.

Sergeant Dorsey, you know, looking at some of the text messages that he was sending and the person he was communicating with, I don't think was the subject of any of these text messages.  And it's obvious that he should not be a police officer or a sheriff's deputy.  Do you think this is criminal conduct, what he was saying?

Well, we know it's criminal because he was charged with a felony.  And so, you know, clearly he has... issues.  He has probably some anger management.  He's probably uber aggressive out there in the field with the community members.  I would imagine to think there's something in his personnel history that let them know that he was somebody who bears watching.  And so when people tell you who they are, you should believe them.  And you don't get to commit crimes to stop crimes, and so absolutely he had to go.  The fact that he's a police officer does not exempt him from being arrested when he commits crimes.

All right, we've got a lot more crime time straight ahead, plus this.  What impact will COVID have on the George Floyd murder trial on March 8th?  Will it be safe inside and outside of the courtroom?  And will the defense say COVID was a contributing factor in the death of George Floyd?  And the husband of a missing mom in Chula Vista, California speaks out.  What do you think about what Larry Millett said about his wife, Maya?  Go to our Facebook pages and tell us what you think.  And what do you think happened?
Where do you think she is?
Before I wasn't really worried.  You know, I was kind of like worried, but, you know, I wasn't like totally worried until the birthday.

Another one of the stories we're covering tonight in our Crime Time segment.  Still with us, Sergeant Cheryl Dorsey and Lieutenant Colonel Adam Lee III.  Our next story, KGTV in San Diego had a unique opportunity to speak with Larry Miglietti, whose wife, Maya, is missing.  So the husband gave this interview, spoke out, kind of told his story, his version of what is happening.  Let's take a listen.

Thursday, Thursday night, you know, like we got into a kind of an argument and, you know, we've been having, you know, like problems.  Um, you know, for about a year, we've kind of like been up and down and stuff like that.  But after that, you know, I give her space on Friday.

Um, I could still hear, but I didn't physically see her when I got home, but that's like normal too, because we, you know, we have lots of bedrooms, there's two story house and, you know, we kind of like, well, I give her space.

So, but that's why every time someone says, um, Thursday, yes, it's physically, you know, or visually.  It's Friday night.  I can hear her wrestling around, making dinner for herself in another bedroom.

I'm sleeping with the kids in another bedroom.  So upstairs and she's downstairs kind of deal.  Kind of like a roommate thing.  Kind of like giving each other space.  Well, I don't need the space.  She always wants the space.  Got it.  So it was like Friday and then you left or went, went somewhere and then came back and she wasn't there, right?

Yes.  I left her with my two girls cause they, you know, they, um, uh, do their homes, homeschool.  And then I just had my son with me.  So, uh, when I came back, she was still there on Friday.  Um, we can hear her downstairs, you know, like after I'm done giving the kids baths and feeding them and everything.  And, um, On Saturday morning, when her parents came by, her door was locked.  I found the keys to the bedroom, and I opened it, and she was already gone.  So maybe she went through a morning sunrise hike, you know, because she didn't go jeeping because that's one of her other hobbies, the jeep group.  And, you know, she would have taken that.  So I assumed maybe one of her friends She likes to go one tasting Temecula.  That's her other thing or brunch early morning.  Yeah.  After that, you know, like at night where, okay, she hasn't come home yet, which is sometimes okay.  You know, she'd go out maybe for drinks or something.  She usually doesn't drink a lot, but recently she's been, you know, doing that.  You know, the latest she would be home like 2.30 or, you know, 3.30 in the morning.  After that, that's kind of like...

out of the ordinary.  All right, we've got our investigators here.  What do you think of what the husband said?  We still don't know where Maya is.  There are no named suspects in the case.  But Lieutenant Colonel Adam Lee III, you've investigated many, many cases.  What did you think of what the husband had to say?

There wasn't a whole lot to go on right there, but he seemed to be very calm.  He wasn't nervous.  He didn't seem to be untruthful.  I mean, he was honest that they were having some marital problems.  So a lot of times it's hard to tell when the person that is giving the information admits that there were marital problems.  He doesn't really give you a lot to go on right there.  So there's a lot more that needs to be done with talking to friends and family of her to see if there was ever any threats made by him.

Sergeant Dorsey, you know, looking at this investigation that is taking place now, they've got three children, and apparently the husband, Larry, is taking care of the kids, and her sisters and family are kind of leading the search efforts to try to find her.  One interesting thing I heard him say there, though, was that her bedroom was locked.  So this is a couple that I, it's obvious they've got problems if they have separate bedrooms.

Well, listen, I call BS because, um, you know, they've got small children according to the pictures that we saw and he gets up in the morning and she's gone.  Uh, we didn't hear him at least in the snippet that you played say anything about trying to reach her on his cell phone.  He was concerned that she went off and left the kids, uh, in the bottom half of the house, uh, basically unsupervised, not knowing when she's going to come back.  And so, uh, The husband is always the suspect.  And now that he's crafted this story and put it out there, investigators will have an opportunity to have a real in-depth interview with him somewhere down the road and then compare what he says in a subsequent interview.  as far as what he said publicly.  Maybe he's speaking to an audience of, you know, however many are in her family to throw them off the case.  I don't believe any of what he said.  How could you not be concerned?  Even if you aren't getting along, you got small kids.  The kids should be wondering, where's mom?  What is he saying to them?  I call BS.

And Lieutenant Colonel, you know, She missed the 11-year-old's birthday.  Does it seem to you, because there's many possibilities here, like something could have happened to her, she could voluntarily have stepped away.  To me, it would be hard to convince me that a mother of three young children like that first would miss the birthday without saying anything and then just leave those children.

That's absolutely out of the ordinary.  That's something that the police need to definitely focus on.  Because it's not often that a mother will miss her child's birthday unless she is suffering from some sort of depression herself.  That could explain it away.  When they talk to relatives and friends, they need to find out just how close she was to her daughters.  It's quite possible.  We've seen mothers leave their children.  So that's not just an obvious sign.  It's something that's definitely worth taking some more looks into.
Sergeant Dorsey, the other thing is, if she left, she left her vehicle at home.

Right, and did she leave without her purse, other things that she would normally have with her?  These are things that, in my mind, would give me pause as an investigator.  And this husband is just too lackadaisical You know, no big deal.  We, you know, we live separate lives.  But at the end of the day, there are small children who were abandoned by this woman.  And at the very least, for his children's sake, he should have a little more concern, I think, unless he's responsible for her missing.
All right.

Sergeant Cheryl Dorsey, Lieutenant Colonel Adam Lee III, always great to have you two on the program.  Appreciate your time and expertise tonight.  Please come back.  Thank you.  All right, folks, when we come back, we're going to bring in our legal think tank, take a look at some big legal stories of the day, including the George Floyd case, the doomsday couple.  We'll also get your 13th juror answers to what the husband of the missing mom had to say.  That's coming up next time.
